around the margin of the previously-formed disk; and that the deposit of
calcareous matter forming the shelly walls of the cells and passages, takes
place •	Use <u>upon</u>, or rather •	Use <u>in</u>, the superficial portion of this zone of sarcode - But
I cannot find any evidence in the ordinary growth of the disk, that
the sarcode extends itself over the surface of the portion previously
formed; although occasional appearances will be hereafter described
(§ 53), that seem to indicate that it <u>may</u> do so.
 
<s>The arrangement and connections of the concentric zones of cells, which
surround the nucleus, are well displayed by a horizontal section of the disk
(Plate II, Fig 2). Each zone consists of a set of small circular or oval cells (Plate I, Fig. 9)
excavated, as it were, in the substance of the shell, and communicating with
each other laterally by passages, which unite them together into a complete
annulus. The zone which immediately surrounds the nucleus is connected
with it by passages, which extend from the outer margin of the large
circumambient cell, to several cells, of which it is itself composed, and
each zone communicates with the one on its exterior by similar passages
which usually extend, however, not from the cells of the inner zone to
those of the outer, but from the <u>connecting passages</u> of the inner zone to the
cells of the</s>
